reviewText: I like Aaron Kwok. He has a lot of detractors who call him wooden and full of hot air, but I've enjoyed him in movies like 2000 AD and China Strike Force. But it really pains me to see him act like such an annoying and dense character in City Under Siege. It's supposed to be a running joke in the movie that he's an idiot, but it's not the least bit funny.He stars as a circus performer in a traveling troupe. One day, they all discover strange chemicals underground, and for no reason at all, Aaron's fellow performers turn on him and become evil. Then they get mutated with augmented strength and start a rampage. Aaron also gets mutated which doesn't alter his looks, but makes him an expert knife thrower.Shu Qi plays a news reporter who gets fired in favor of someone younger. .........Yeah right. She meets Aaron and they end up having some of the worst romantic chemistry of the year.As mentioned before, the villains have no motivation to be villains and are just ridiculous. Colin Chou is their leader, and his mutant makeup looks awful. The script also requires him to be a whiny crybaby who has fits of rage.Wu Jing also has a role as a cop tracking down the mutants. He looks like he should be the star of the film, but is completely out of place playing second fiddle to Aaron Kwok. His character also proves to be unlikeable when he proclaims that the mutants are freaks who need to be tortured and given autopsies.One of the characters also has a girlfriend who dies simply to force emotion out of the audience, and it comes across as cheap.After scoring big with New Police Story and Invisible Targets, it's a wonder how Benny Chan can direct a film with so little action. The fight scenes are very short, and instead of cool choreography it's a mix of gimmicky CGI and lame comedic antics.This film is a waste of time, and I can't believe US distributors would want to expose this to potential audiences.
summary: Annoying and melodramatic with little action
Title: N/A

reviewText: I waited a while to pen a review for CITY UNDER SIEGE.  Basically, I was hoping that distancing myself from the experience might actually help me come up with something a bit more positive to say about the motion picture, but, after racking my brain for about two weeks plus, I'm still coming up with nothing substantial.  I'll give it a go anyway.  I'll just warn you to brace yourselves.Sunny (played by Aaron Kwok) is a "lowly circus clown" who dreams of one day mastering the art of knive-throwing.  One night, some of the circus's other players taunt Sunny to join them on a quest to find some treasure lost in a local subterranean cave.  Instead of gold, they find the remains of a long-buried military-grade nerve gas that, when inhaled, gives them a mutant ability, each according to their already given circus talents.  Now, Sunny is all that stands against the evil mutant circus performers in their plot to destroy the city.Yes.  That's the plot.  That's all there is folks.Now, to be fair, there's something to be said for films that embrace their own inner lunacy.  Some films - say BILL AND TED'S EXCELLENT ADVENTURE, for example - embrace a goofy premise and end up fully entertaining the audience so long as no one looks too closely at the material.  Indeed, one need look no further than the first ACE VENTURA film to know that American audiences can embrace even a dithering idiot - lovable he may be - for the purposes of satisfying a craving for entertainment.  Some of the fun in flicks of this variety comes from the secondary characters who are trusted to interact with the lead; we marvel at their ability to keep a straight face, we laugh at their obvious frustration in trying to accomplish basic tasks, and we even find delight when they mug to the audience for a good laugh.  Unfortunately, none of that happens here.  The humor falls flat, and, aside from a handful of respectably directed action sequences, there's nothing to marvel at.Again, dare I invoke Yoda?  "Great action sequences do not a film make."  Didn't mankind learn as much from the second MATRIX film?  True, there's something to be said for relevance and context, and, while it may all look very pretty in high def glory, it's still all befuddling as to how a mistake of this magnitude got made.  Ever.  In any country.Sadly, the lovely Shu Qui of the first TRANSPORTER film (and many, many other vastly superior flicks, too) is utterly wasted as reporter and love interest here.  Most of the time, her expressions are just flat.  I'm not certain as to whether she's lost in the source material or lost somewhere in her career, trying to figure out how she found herself in the middle of this cinematic nightmare.  Certainly, the rest of the cast deserves to be congratulated because, as mutants, they all appear to have bought into the premise; they fight, they grimace, they posture convincingly - each and every one of them - but they're paid actors, now that I think of it, so they're only doing their job.  At least, they had layers of make-up to protect them from being recognized.Today as preparation, I've read a handful of reviews regarding CITY online, and I have to admit that I'm utterly flummoxed by how some critics have rated this picture so highly.  Their primary argument?  Well, they appear to all have taken the stance that "It's only a film."  You'll have to forgive me if I expect better.  I have no problem with `guilty pleasures,' but there's shockingly little to respect in a flick like CITY UNDER SIEGE.  Reasonable effects aside, don't be fooled.  This CITY is best left to the mutants.Not recommended.In the interests of fairness, I'm pleased to share that the kind folks at FUNimation provided me with a screener copy for the purposes of completing this review.
summary: CITY UNDER SIEGE Is A Nightmare Captured on Film!  (Not the good kind)

reviewText: Probably those who are looking forward to seeing some intense, Jet Li-type martial action stunts will be disappointed with "City Under Siege," a sort of an answer from Hong Kong filmmakers to the current Hollywood superhero blockbusters. Unlike his "New Police Story" or "Shaolin," Director Benny Chan takes a more light-hearted approach to the familiar story about good and evil, with special effects-ridden fights between a superhero and supervillains, but the end result is really a mixed bag.The film is about "Sunny" (Aaron Kwok), a clown of a traveling circus troupe (and a son of a renowned knife throwing master). One day, while looking for gold in a Malaysian cave, he and other circus members including circus troupe leader Zhang Dachu (Collin Chou) are exposed to the chemical gas developed by the Japanese army just before WWII ended.But you may skip the dull introductory part. About 40 minutes in, the real story begins with Zhang Dachu and his gang, who have transformed into superhuman "monsters" robbing the jewelry stores and banks in Hong Kong; and Sunny, who gained superhuman powers apparently without changing physical appearance. Shu Qi plays Angel, a TV reporter covering the story of Sunny. Wu Jing and Zhang Jingchu are special agents.The film has a few action set-pieces that are watchable but not remarkable. Wu Jing and Collin Chou show what they can do in the martial arts action scenes, but there are not many, and cheesy special effects of flying knives do not help. Aaron Kwok's reluctant hero remains uninteresting, and so does Shu Qi's opportunistic reporter. Benny Chan attempt to explore the characters' inner psyche or soul by introducing romances and father-son relationship, but none is convincing.Silly and uneven "City Under Siege" could have been a more entertaining romp with a tighter story and better effects.
summary: (2.5 STARS) Keep Your Expectation Level Low and You May Enjoy This Silly Actioner
